comments:
hi,

i work with eclipse under fedora core 2 on a 3,1 GHz P4(hyper-threading) with
1024 MB-Ram and 1024 MB swap space. because i work on different big java
projects i add the following commands to the eclipse starter: -vmargs -Xms512M
-Xmx1024M

the problem is that i get OutOfMemory-Exceptions every-time i clean my complete
workspace with all projects open. when i often use the F3 feature 'Open
declaration', i also get OutOfMemory-Exceptions sometimes.

but everytime i i check the memory in top after a OutOfMemory-Exception, top
shows me that the java process 'only' uses ~300MB(20%) of the complete memory
and i also have 250-350MB free memory and 1024MB free swap space.

java/eclipse don't use the memory i've configured...

Instead of using the native launcher, could you try running Eclipse with the
following:

cd <eclipse-install>
java -Xms512M -Xmx1024M -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main

Does the problem still occur?

BTW: -Xms is the initial size of the memory allocation pool, so should not help
you in case of OOMErrors.

i got the following errors when i want to start eclipse with this command: java
-Xms512M -Xmx1024M -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main

Sorry, my fault. The correct command-line should be:

java -Xms512M -Xmx1024M -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -os linux
-ws gtk

You are running Eclipse-GTK, right?

cool, now it works!
but why can't i use the eclipse executable with -vmargs?
for what do i need the -Xms argument?

Could you try running with the native launcher again? Just open Help>About
Eclipse Platform>Configuration Details. Please paste here the values of the
eclipse.vm and eclipse.vmargs properties.

So, for some reason, no VM args (other than the ones added by the launcher are
being passed to the VM. Michael, how did you run Eclipse for this last test 
(command-line/shortcut)? Is that how you usually run Eclipse (when you get the
out-of-memory problems)?

i run eclipse with this command: eclipse -vmargs -Xms512M -Xmx1024M
yes, this is how i usually run eclipse.

So you always run from the command line shell. Last question: any chance you
have an "eclipse" script anywhere in your system path? A good check for that
would be: change into the Eclipse install dir, and run: 

./eclipse -vmargs -Xms512M -Xmx1024M

Does the eclipse.vmargs system property still have the exact same value as in
comment 6?

next test:
i changed into the eclipse directory and run: ./eclipse -vmargs -Xms512M -Xmx1024M
...and now it works! :-)
...i only have a link from /usr/local/bin/ to /opt/eclipse/eclipse

I do not understand why using a link would strip command line arguments, but it
is clear this is not related to Eclipse itself. Let us know if you have any
information on the contrary.

Closing.
